Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Multidisciplinary Framework for Innovative Design of Wind Turbines

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Kivanc Ekici

Institution: University of Tennessee-Knoxville

Title: CAREER: A Multidisciplinary Framework for Innovative Design of Wind Turbines

With renewed emphasis on energy independence, there is an increased need to improve the reliability, efficiency and performance of current and future power generation technologies. It is clear that the wind turbine technology will play a vital role in ensuring the nation's energy independence. However, structural failure of wind turbine blades leading to high maintenance costs and intermittent operation is common, and accurate prediction of unsteady aerodynamic forces acting on wind turbine blades remains elusive.

It is critical to focus attention on the development of novel high fidelity analysis and design techniques that are 10 to 100 times faster than what is currently available. This project will integrate research and education to investigate and devise novel methods for wind turbine design technology with greatly decreased computational cost, while educating next generation of wind energy engineers. The project will improve complex multi-physics understanding by establishing an elegant approach for innovative wind turbine designs. The education component of the plan will focus on training students who translate the proposed research into real-world applications.

Intellectual Merit
This project will investigate unsteady aerodynamic modeling and rapid design of wind turbines by developing and applying two very efficient computational methods - a "multi-frequency" harmonic balance method and an adjoint method - which will be used in an optimization algorithm to design innovative wind turbines with improved aerodynamic, aeroelastic, and aeroacoustic characteristics. Furthermore, sensitivity information will be used to quantify uncertainty in unsteady flow predictions. Design optimization methods developed for wind turbines are directly applicable to turbomachinery used in aircraft engines and land-based power generators. Current designs may be improved for increased fuel efficiency, better aeromechanic characteristics, and increased safety.

Broader Impacts
The educational and outreach plan includes development of a wind engineering course and a wind turbine aerodynamics and aeroelasticity course. Other activities include training of next-generation researchers, involving undergraduate students in cutting-edge research, and participating in summer outreach programs that target high school teachers and K-12 students. Outreach efforts will be augmented by collaborations with an established Professor of Teacher and Science Education and the College of Engineering's Office of Academic and Student Affairs. Finally, an executable version of computational tools developed in this project will be made available to interested parties for research use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this NSF CAREER plan was to integrate research and education to investigate and devise novel methods for wind turbine design technology with greatly decreased computational cost, and to educate the next generation of wind energy engineers, researchers and faculty. The proposed research improved complex multi-physics understanding by establishing an elegant approach for innovative wind turbine designs. The educational component of the plan focused on training students, offering related workshops to pre-service K-12 science teachers, developing new graduate and undergraduate level courses in the departmental curriculum. Specific objectives that were set at the beginning of the project were accomplished and those resulted in many scientific journal manuscripts, conference papers and presentations. Furthermore, students who were supported through this project gained employment as researchers, faculty members as well as postdoctoral researchers. Below is the summary of research and educational outcomes.

Research outcomes:

  1. We developed state-of-the-art computational methodologies and tools to efficiently investigate longstanding challenges in unsteady aerodynamic modeling and rapid design of wind turbines. Our approach included the development and application of two very efficient computational methods: (a) the “multi-frequency” harmonic balance (HB) method – a variation of the time-periodic HB technique for the analysis of periodic and aperiodic unsteady flows such as those arising from self-excited/forced blade vibrations, wake/blade interactions and wind shear; and (b) the adjoint method to determine the sensitivity of a small number of objective functions to design variables, which may number in the hundreds or thousands. These two methods were used as part of an optimization algorithm to design innovative wind turbines with improved aerodynamic, aeroelastic, and aeroacoustic characteristics.
  2. As a result of the research activities, our group has published 12 manuscripts in top journals in our area. In addition, we have published and presented 15 conference papers with additional 3 conference papers to be presented in 2019. Finally, we have 2 more manuscripts that are under review for consideration.
  3. Our research has resulted in the invention of a novel fully-automated computational method to compute adjoint design sensitivities for aerodynamic design. We have filed an Invention Disclosure with the University of Tennessee’s Research Foundation. When ready this tool will be available for dissemination to interested researchers.

Educational outcomes:

  1. This project provided invaluable resources that supported many undergraduate and graduate researchers. A number of the undergraduate students stayed on to pursue graduate degrees in our research group. Of the graduate students who earned their degrees, 2 are currently faculty members (one Assistant Professor of Mechanical Engineering at The Citadel, and one Associate Professor of Power and Energy at Northwestern Polytechnical University in China). Another recent graduate is currently a Postdoc in our research group and is on track to become a future faculty member. In addition, one of the students who was partially supported through this project has gained employment as a Senior Mechanical Engineer at Raytheon in Tucson, AZ. There are currently two PhD candidates who are scheduled to earn their degrees in May 2019. One of those students has gained employment as a Senior Research Scientist at the CFDRC Research Corporation in Huntsville, AL before graduation. 
  2. The PI has developed 2 new courses (both at the senior undergrad and graduate levels) and has taught these courses alternatingly every Spring semester. The interest for the courses has been very positive with 15-20 students enrolling on the average.
  3. In collaboration with a Science Teacher Education faculty member at UT, our team has developed and organized workshops to pre-service science teachers who have gained full time employment in the local area school after graduation. The graduate students have designed and carried out experiments for these workshops.

Summary of outcomes:

Our team was able to accomplish each task that was identified at the beginning and the outcomes have been very positive thanks to the support provided by the National Science Foundation.
